HST 071
[H1] IN SUMMARY.
[H1] TEMPERATURE AND THE TESTES.
[H2] TEMPERATURE AND THE TESTIS.
[H3] Historical.
[LIST_ITEM] Greece, -heat was related to vitality
[LIST_ITEM] Large penis was considered less desirable
[LIST_ITEM] Thought to allow the semen to cool during ejaculation
[LIST_ITEM] Recognized for centuries that cryptorchidism - results in sterility
[LIST_ITEM] Core body temperature is actually lethal for the male germ cells
[LIST_ITEM] Humans & many other mammals - extracorporeal pouch (scrotum)
[LIST_ITEM] Not universal among mammals
[LIST_ITEM] 1/3 mammals maintain testes internally (elephant, rhinoceros, aquatic mammals..)
[LIST_ITEM] Does not exist at all among birds, reptiles, amphibians, or fish
[LIST_ITEM] Unique among the body's organs – vulnerability
[H3] Evolutionary benefit.
[LIST_ITEM] Cool scrotal environment - greater sperm storage within the epididymis
[LIST_ITEM] Greatest benefit to the seasonal breeder (not humans !!!)
[H3] Anatomy and Physiology.
Five main anatomic features that allow the testes to remain cool
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Dartos muscle
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Cremaster muscle
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Countercurrent heat exchange system,
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Absent fatty skin layer
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Abundant sweat glands
[H3] Clinical Aspects.
Causes of male infertility related to heat
[LIST_ITEM] varicocele,
[LIST_ITEM] cryptorchidism
[LIST_ITEM] fever
Early correction of cryptorchidism results in improved fertility
Unilateral cryptorchidism can cause significant subfertility
[H3] Varicoceles.
[LIST_ITEM] Dilated veins in the scrotum
[LIST_ITEM] Become fuller with standing position
[LIST_ITEM] First noted by Celsus (born in 25 AD)
[LIST_ITEM] Intratesticular and scrotal temperature - higher in men with varicoceles,
[LIST_ITEM] Pampiniform plexus of veins
[LIST_ITEM] Carries blood from the testis through the spermatic cord
[LIST_ITEM] Coalescing into the testicular vein(s)
[LIST_ITEM] Travel upwards in the retroperitoneum
[LIST_ITEM] Finally drain into the renal vein on the left
[LIST_ITEM] Inferior vena cava on the right
[H3] Incompetent Valves.
[LIST_ITEM] Gravity pulls blood down into the scrotum
[LIST_ITEM] Veins become dilated.
[LIST_ITEM] Blood from retroperitoneum is at core temperature
[LIST_ITEM] Reflux of this relatively warm blood
[LIST_ITEM] Contributes to the scrotal warming
Varicoceles can also cause a reduction of serum testosterone level

[H1] Basic science.
[LIST_ITEM] When stem spermatogonia have been lost - no capability for spermatogenesis to recover
[LIST_ITEM] First cellular manifestations of heat exposure - condensation of nuclear components (pyknosis),
[LIST_ITEM] P53 highly expressed in testes
[LIST_ITEM] Apoptosis form of cell death in biologic systems - loss of germ cells in response to heat
[LIST_ITEM] Longest stage (pachytene) – crossover and DNA exchange, ability to repair breaks
[LIST_ITEM] Time-temperature threshold
[H1] Heat and Male Contraception.
Insulating the underwear of male volunteers
[LIST_ITEM] Significant drop in sperm concentration and motility
[LIST_ITEM] Change in scrotal temperature of only 1°C
[LIST_ITEM] Unreliable form of contraception
[H1] Controversy.
No temperature differences were noted between men wearing tight or loose underwear in one study while sperm count twice as high in another
